raw_text:
Blair sets date for Africa report
 
 The Commission for Africa's report will be released on 11 March - Comic Relief day, Tony Blair has said.
 
 July's G8 summit in Gleneagles in Perthshire - chaired by the prime minister - will use the report as the basis for talks on Africa. The announcement followed the final meeting of the commission - which includes singer Bob Geldof - in London. As well as more aid, fairer trade and less debt, the commission is likely to demand action on corruption in Africa. Mr Blair told a news conference: "It will be a report that's brutally frank about the reality, but I hope idealistic about what can be done if the will is there. "It's an ambitious project we have set ourselves and you will have to judge on its outcome when we publish it."
 
 Mr Blair has vowed to put Africa at the top of his agenda during his time at the helm of the G8. He acknowledged he would have a "a job of persuading to do" on other nations to get the necessary commitment to debt relief. Bob Geldof, in characteristically blunt style, promised that the commission would not just be a talking shop but would deliver radical new thinking to change direction for Africa. The former rock star's presence on the commission has been interpreted as a sign that it will be uncompromising in its demands. The people involved include two African government leaders and a range of other African politicians, as well as experts from some other developed countries.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair will release the Commission for Africa report on March 11, Comic Relief day.
The report is expected to demand action on corruption, fairer trade, and less debt in Africa.
A G8 summit chaired by Blair will use the report's findings, with the goal of publishing it soon after.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair announces Commission for Africa's report release date of March 11 as Comic Relief day; July's G8 summit to discuss Africa issues based on the report; commission demands more aid, fairer trade, and debt reduction, with a focus on corruption in Africa.
gemma2:2b: The Commission for Africa will release its report on March 11th (Comic Relief Day).
The report will use the findings to shape talks about Africa at the G8 summit, with demands for increased aid, fairer trade, less debt, and action against corruption.
Tony Blair emphasized that the report will be honest about challenges but hopeful about potential solutions if there is political will.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The G8 summit chair Tony Blair announced that the Commission for Africa's report on Africa will be released on March 11 following Comic Relief day.
Blair has vowed to put Africa at the top of his agenda during his time in the G8 leadership, while Bob Geldof promised a radical new approach to change direction for African nations.
The report would address issues such as aid, fair trade, debt relief and corruption in Africa.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Blair-led Commission for Africa will release its report on 11 March (Comic Relief day), using G8 summit's findings to discuss aid, trade fairness, debt reduction, and corruption in Africa.
The commission aims to achieve radical change despite being "brutally frank" about the current state of Africa.
qwen2.5:3b: Blair sets date for Africa report release on 11 March - Comic Relief day.
The G8 summit in Gleneagles will use the report to discuss aid, fairer trade, less debt, and action on corruption.
The commission includes Tony Blair, Bob Geldof, two African government leaders, other African politicians, and experts from developed countries.

smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the text.
It does not provide any explanations or justifications for the events mentioned in the text.
The summary only presents the facts as they are presented in the original text.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Mr. Tony Blair is set to release his Africa report on March 11, Comic Relief day in Australia.
The G8 summit, held in Perthshire, will use this report for discussions on Africa.
The summit was chaired by Blair, who acknowledged needing persuasive support from other nations for debt relief.
The commission aims to address aid, fairer trade, less debt, and rising corruption.
Bob Geldof's blunt comments are seen as a signal of the commission's demands.
Blair's tenure at G8 involves setting Africa high, despite the need for persuasion from others.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Commission for Africa is expected to deliver a report on 11 March, which will use the findings of the report as a basis for talks on aid, trade, and debt relief in sub-Saharan Africa.
The final meeting of the commission took place in London last week, with Tony Blair stating that it would be an "ambitious project" aiming to get African nations to take action.
He voiced his hope that the G8 will follow suit by putting Africa at the top of their agenda and committing more aid and fairer trade in order to improve living conditions for Africans.
The commission's chairman, Bob Geldof, promised radical new thinking to change direction for Africa, while the people involved include African leaders and experts from different developed countries.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Sure, I can summarize the information here: Blair sets date for Africa report, to be released on March 11th.
He is also planning G8 summit in Gleneagles to use the report as basis for trade and aid discussions with African leaders, including Bob Geldof from charity group Comic Relief.
Blair wants a report that will be "brutally frank about the reality", but still hopeful about what can be done if the will is there.
He also plans to persuade nations like China and America to commit more funds for debt relief, as well as demand action on corruption in Africa.
The commission, which includes singer Bob Geldof, aims to make significant changes to improve lives in Africa.

Bob Geldof, who will be on the commission, has expressed that it won't just be a talk shop but will deliver radical new thinking.
